title: The Hodge Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Every Hodge class on a projective variety is a rational combination of algebraic cycle classes.

overview.historicalContext: The Hodge Conjecture (1950) concerns the relationship between topology and algebraic geometry. It became a Millennium Prize Problem in 2000 with a $1M prize.
overview.problemStatement:
**Conjecture:** On a smooth projective variety X over C, every Hodge class is a rational linear combination of algebraic cycle classes.

Formally: H^{p,p}(X) intersect H^{2p}(X,Q) equals the Q-span of algebraic subvariety classes.
overview.proofStrategy:

1. Abstract definitions of Hodge structures

3. Proven cases (Lefschetz theorem for divisors)

keyInsights: The conjecture is OPEN - one of the Millennium Prize Problems
The Lefschetz (1,1) theorem is the proven case for divisors
Voisin showed it fails for Kahler manifolds with integral coefficients

conclusion.summary: The Hodge Conjecture remains open. This formalization provides the mathematical framework and statement, along with known special cases.
conclusion.implications: The conjecture is fundamental to algebraic geometry and topology. Its resolution would have profound implications for our understanding of algebraic varieties.
